{{multiple issues| {{COI|date=February 2015}} {{POV|date=February 2015}} {{citation style|date=February 2015}} {{unreliable sources|date=February 2015}} }} [[File:Shrine of Sayed Ziaul Haq Photo by Naidu.jpg|thumbnail|Shrine of Sayed Ziaul Haq]] '''Sayed Ziaul Haq''' ({{lang-bn|ছৈয়দ জিয়াউল হক}}; 1928–1988) was a [[Sufism|Sufi]] saint of the Maizbhanderi Sufi order,<ref name="Maizbhanderi Order 3">{{cite web|url=http://www.edainikazadi.net/eazadi.php?page=12&subpage=1&date=2014-01-21 |title=Benglali News Media: The Daily Azadi, Title: The ORS Festival of Gaus-e-Azam Maizbhanderi since today, Published on: January 21, 2014, Last page, 3rd column}}</ref> also known as Bisso Wali<ref name="Zia Baba 5">{{cite web|url=http://www.timewatch.com.bd/2014/10/11/6811 |title=Annual ORS Shaif of Shahenshah Hadrath Sayed Ziaul Haq Maizbhanderi/ শাহানশাহ হযরত সৈয়দ জিয়াউল হক মাইজভান্ডারীর (ক:) বার্ষিক ওরশ (Maizbhander Sharif became an ocean of people by millions of affectionate desiring to attend the ORS Sharif of Bishwa Wali ShahenShah Hadrath Sayed Ziaul Haq Maizbhanderi/ বিশ্বঅলি শাহানশাহ হযরত সৈয়দ জিয়াউল হক মাইজভান্ডারীর বার্ষিক ওরশ শরিফ উপলক্ষে লাখো আশেক ভক্ত অংশগ্রহণে মুখরিত হয়ে উঠেছে মাইজভান্ডার শরিফ), |author= Daily Time Watch |date= October 11, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Zia Baba 8">{{cite web|url=http://www.banglapostbd.com/%E0%A6%AE%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%87%E0%A6%9C%E0%A6%AD%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A8%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A1%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B0%E0%A7%80-%E0%A6%97%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%89%E0%A6%9B%E0%A6%BF%E0%A7%9F%E0%A6%BE-%E0%A6%B9%E0%A6%95/ |title= জিয়াউল হক মাইজভান্ডারীর ওরশে ভক্তের ঢল/ Steam of massive affectionate at the ORS of Ziaul Haq Maizbhanderi (Millions of people at 26th ORS Sharif of Bishwa Wali Sahenshah Hadrath Sayed Ziaul Haq Maizbhanderi.../ বিশ্বঅলি শাহানশাহ হযরত সৈয়দ জিয়াউল হক মাইজভান্ডারী (ক.) এর ২৬ তম বার্ষিক ওরশ শরিফ লাখো ভক্ত-আশেকের উচ্ছ্বাসমুখর অংশগ্রহণে...), |author= Daily Ajadi |date= October 12, 2014}}</ref> ({{lang-bn|বিশ্ব অলী}}), Shahenshah<ref name="Zia Baba 5"/><ref name="Zia Baba 8"/> ({{lang-bn|শাহেনশাহ}}), Zia Baba ({{lang-bn|জিয়া বাবা}}) and Shahenshah Hadrath [[Sayyid|Sayed]] Ziaul Haq Maizbhanderi Kaddasa Sirhul Ajiz ({{lang-bn|শাহেনশাহ হযরত ছৈয়দ জিয়াউল হক মাইজভান্ডারী কাদ্দাছা ছিরহুল আজিজ}}).<ref name="Zia Baba 8"/>
==Born== He was born at Maizbhandar in [[Chittagong District|Chittagong district]], British India (now [[Bangladesh]]) on Tuesday morning, 25th of December 1928; [[Poush]] 10, 1335 [[Bengali calendar|BC]]; Rajab 12, l347 [[Islamic calendar|AH]]. Initially he was named as Sayed Badiur Rahman on the 7th day of his birth. Hence, his father [[Sayed Delaor Husaein]] renamed him as Sayed Ziaul Haq according to a heavenly commandment and mother [[Sayyid|Sayeda]] Sajeda Khatun was the 2nd daughter of [[Golamur Rahman Maizbhandari|Baba Bhanderi]].<ref name="Ziaul Haq Website 13">{{cite web|url=http://www.sufimaizbhandari.org/shahenshah_hazrat_shah_sufi_syed_ziaul_huq_maizbhandari.html |title=Shahanshah Hazrat Moulana Shah Sufi Sayed Ziaul Haq Maizbhandari|author= Maizbhander Sharif an emblem of human regalement|date=}}</ref><ref name="ZiaBaba Wasel 9">{{cite book |author=Jamal Ahmed Shikdar |date=2010 |orig-year=First published 1982 |title=শাহানশাহ জিয়াউল হক মাইজভান্ডারী |trans-title=Shahenshah Ziaul Haq Maizbhandari |url=http://www.sufimaizbhandari.org/Biography%20of%20Shahenshah%20Hazrat%20Syed%20Ziaul%20Haq%20Maizbhandari.pdf |language=bn |edition=9th |page=}}</ref>{{page needed|date=May 2017}}<!-- Need to say which page(s) of the book supports the paragraph about his birth. -->
==Education== Firstly, house tutor Moulavi Mozammel Haq taught him the [[Arabic]] alphabetic elementary level, Then had been learning up-to class three at Maizbhandar Ahmadia Junior Madrasa He get admitted at class five and studied up-to eight at Nanupur Abu Sobhan High School. Latterly, studied class nine-ten and passed the Entrance Examination from [[Chittagong Collegiate School and College|Chittagong Collegiate School]] in 1949. After accomplishing intermediate Level (I.A.) from [[Chittagong College]], while as a student of Kanongopara Sir Ashotos Government Degree College of Boalkhali, appeared at 3rd examination of Bachelor Degree (B.A.), his condition became unstable having mysterious experience, in fact, came out of the examination hall submitting blank answer script, that remain the enclosing remark of his institutional education.<ref name="Ziaul Haq Website 13"/>
==Sufi perspective== It is firmly known that, encountering such a spiritual experience, he straightly returned to Maizbhander at Fatikchari from Boalkhali. Since them, his mysteriously eventful life get an esoteric state of Sufi . While Sufi meditation (Reajat/[[Muraqaba]]/Moshaheda) he sometimes used to refuse food and remain consistently sleepless for several days, very often he used to dive in severe cold pound water even in intensive winter season for a couple of days. Meanwhile, he also used to stay alone in a closed door room being detached from all mundane intercourse for days long.<ref name="Ziaul Haq Website 13"/>
There has noted in various published [[hagiography]], while his father was upset regarding son's abnormal attitude, get a Sainthood inspiration in dream by Sayed Ahmed Ullah Maizbhanderi saying, "Why are you so anxious? Let you ware him my green long Cloak (jubba)". The father immediately put the dress wearing on his son, since then, Sayed Ziaul Haq's attitude get a remarkable change remaining calm and quiet. Hagiographers noted him as a Majjub-e-Salek ({{lang-bn|মজ্জুবে ছালেক দরবেশ}}/ ({{lang-ar|الصّوفي المجذوب السالك}}),<ref name="Ziaul Haq Website 13"/> used to travel over days across hills, forest, seaside and different places sleeplessly without any pre-arrangement. He is memorable for a huge number of mysterious/Karamath events. He succeeded the spiritual chain/Shajrah of his Sufi Master as well as father, that goes to Sayed Ahmed Ullah Maizbhanderi through Sayed Aminul Haq Wasel (Choto Moulana).<ref name="ZiaBaba Wasel 9"/>
==Sobriquet== Among millions<ref name="Zia Baba 5"/><ref name="Zia Baba 8"/> of affectionate throughout the world, he is well-known through some [[sobriquet]], two of those achieved noteworthy status. Bishaw Wali ({{lang-bn|বিশ্ব অলী}})<ref name="Zia Baba 5"/><ref name="Zia Baba 8"/> can be translated as the Universal Sufi Saint or Global Sufi is his most used title. Followers also used to utter him as Shahenshah Babajan ({{lang-bn|শাহেনশাহ বাবাজান}})<ref name="Zia Baba 5"/><ref name="Zia Baba 8"/> since his early age of meditation.<ref name="Ziaul Haq Website 13"/>
==Family== On January 28, 1955, he get married to Sayeda Monwara Begum, the youngest daughter of Late Badaruzzaman Chowdhury (Badan Sikder). On January 16, 1982, his father died, was a [[Sufism|Sufi]] saint<ref name="DelaMoina 1">{{cite web|url=http://dainikpurbokone.net/index.php/-lfontglfont-colorq5a5757qg-lfontg/2013-08-21-19-07-00/23437-2014-03-29-18-10-57 |title=Alhajj Shah Sufi Mufit Abdul Malek Shah Rah – (There inscribe: He learned Sufism from Sayed Delaor Husaein Maizbhanderi, a decentent of the founder of Maizbhanderi Tariqa Hadrath Gauslul Azam Ahmed Ullah Maizbhanderi/অছিয়ে গাউছুল আজম শাহসুফি সৈয়দ দেলাওয়ার হোসাইন আল মাইজভান্ডারী হতে মহান তরীক্বতের শিক্ষা গ্রহন করেন). |author= Daily Purbakon|date= March 30, 2014}}</ref> and a remarkable author. According to the [[Genealogy|genealogical]] lineage he is a descendant of the [[Muhammad|Islamic Prophet Mohammed]], lineage goes to the Prophet <ref name= "Maizbhander Family1">{{cite news |author=Sayed Golam Morshed |date=December 9, 1998 |title=কুতুবুল এরশাদ হযরত মওলানা সৈয়দ আমিনুল হক ওয়াছেল আল-মাইজভান্ডারী (কঃ) |trans-title=Qutub Al-Ershad Hadrath Moulana Sayed Aminul Haque Wasel Al-Maizbhanderi (A) |newspaper=Daily Ajadi |language=bn}}</ref> through [[Abdul-Qadir Gilani|Sayed Abdul Qader Gilani]] and [[Fatimah|Fatimah Zahra]].<ref name="ZiaBaba Wasel 9"/>
==Legacy== He left five daughters and one son. His only son Sayed Muhammad Hasan also known as Mawla Hujur after accomplishing his M.A. in English, acting as the Sajjadanashin<ref name="Zia Baba 8"/><ref name="Zia Baba 4">{{cite web|url=http://www.prothom-alo.com/bangladesh/article/55221/%E0%A6%9C%E0%A6%BF%E0%A7%9F%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%89%E0%A6%B2-%E0%A6%B9%E0%A6%95-%E0%A6%AE%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%87%E0%A6%9C%E0%A6%AD%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A8%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A1%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B0%E0%A7%80%E0%A6%B0-%E0%A6%93%E0%A6%B0%E0%A6%B8-%E0%A6%B6%E0%A6%B0%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%AB |title=ORS Shaif of Ziaul Haq Maizbhanderi/ জিয়াউল হক মাইজভান্ডারীর ওরস শরিফ (Sayed Mohammed Hasan, the Sajjadanashin of Haq Manjil/ হক মনজিলের সাজ্জাদানশীন সৈয়দ মোহাম্মদ হাসান), |author= Daily Prothom Alo|date= October 13, 2013}}</ref> of his Sufi rituals as well as the President of Maizbhandari Academy and Trusty of Shahanshah Hadrath Sayed Ziaul Haq Maizbhandari Trust,<ref name="Zia Baba 5"/> established to spread and publicized Sayed Ziaul Haq's teachings and thought<ref name="Zia Baba 6">{{cite web|url=http://www.timewatch.com.bd/2014/10/11/6811 |title=Conference regarding Shahenshah Hadrath Sayed Ziaul Haq at Hathazari (হাটহাজারী দক্ষিণ মাদার্শা মদুনাঘাট এলাকায় শাহানশাহ হযরত সৈয়দ জিয়াউল হক মাইজভান্ডারী শীর্ষক আলোচনা সভা অনুষ্ঠিত), |author= Daily Banglapost |date= August 5, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Zia Baba 7">{{cite web|url=http://www.banglapostbd.com/%E0%A6%AE%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%87%E0%A6%9C%E0%A6%AD%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A8%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A1%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B0%E0%A7%80-%E0%A6%97%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%89%E0%A6%9B%E0%A6%BF%E0%A7%9F%E0%A6%BE-%E0%A6%B9%E0%A6%95/ |title= Fatheha of Shahenshah Hadrath Sayed Ziaul Haq held at Kashim Bazar (মাইজভান্ডারী গাউছিয়া হক কমিটি বাংলাদেশ হাসিম বাজার শাখার হযরত জিয়াউল হক মাইজভান্ডারী ফাতেহা অনুষ্ঠিত), |author= Daily Banglapost |date= October 25, 2014}}</ref> among the society. The trust is operating a number of Schools, [[Orphanage]], Cultural and social welfare institutes. He is the Organizer of annual International Sufi Conference, Bangladesh.<ref name="ZiaBaba Wasel 9"/>
==Death== He died on October 12, 1988, at the age of 60.<ref name="Ziaul Haq Website 13"/><ref name="ZiaBaba Wasel 9"/>
==Shrine== Nowadays, a latest designed tomb/ [[shrine|majar]] by architect Alamgir Kabir<ref name="Ziaul Haq Shrine 12">{{cite web|url=http://www.dainikdestiny.com/archive/2011/print_news.php?pub_no=139&cat_id=1&menu_id=51&news_type_id=1&index=0 |title= Open Stage of JABI |author= Daily Destiny |date= May 20, 2011}}</ref> having the look of lily constructed since 1993 to 1997, get an status of modern [[monument]].<ref name="Ziaul Haq Shrine 10">{{cite news |title= Shrine of Bishaw Wali Shahenshah will be reconstructed |newspaper=Daily Ajadi |date=June 14, 1989}}</ref><ref name="Ziaul Haq Shrine 11">{{cite news |title= Shrine of Bishaw Wali Shahenshah will be reconstructed |newspaper=Daily Purbakon |date=June 14, 1989}}</ref> Every year, millions of devotees from different countries visit the majar on his ORS Mobarak.<ref name="Zia Baba 5"/><ref name="Zia Baba 8"/><ref name="Ziaul Haq Website 13"/><ref name="Zia Baba 4"/>

revision.text:
{{multiple issues|{{lead rewrite|date=May 2016}} {{technical|date=May 2016}} {{unreliable sources|date=May 2016}} }} {{Sufism|Ideas}}{{Islam}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2014}} Major ideas in '''Sufi metaphysics''' have surrounded the concept of ''weḥdah'' ({{lang|ar|وحدة}}) meaning "unity", or in Arabic {{lang|ar|توحيد}} ''[[tawhid]]''. Two main [[Sufism|Sufi]] [[Islamic philosophy|philosophies]] prevail on this topic. ''waḥdat al-wujūd'' literally means the "Unity of Existence" or "Unity of Being" but better translation would be Monotheism of Existence. Wujud (i.e. existence) here refers to Allah's Wujud - implication is Wahdat/Tawheed Of Wujud Of Allah. On the other hand, ''waḥdat ash-shuhūd'', meaning "Apparentism" or "Monotheism of Witness", holds that [[God in Islam|God]] and his creation are entirely separate.
Some [[Islamic]] reformers have claimed that the difference between the two philosophies differ only in [[semantics]] and that the entire debate is merely a collection of "verbal controversies" which have come about because of ambiguous [[language]]. However, the concept of the relationship between [[God]] and the [[universe]] is still actively debated both among Sufis and between Sufis and non-Sufi [[Muslim]]s.
== Waḥdat al-Wujūd (Unity of Existence)== The [[philosophy]] of Wahdat al-Wujud was first ever prevailed by [[Husayn ibn Ali]] in his book Mirat-ul-Arifeen which he wrote in response to the question of his son [[Zayn al-Abidin]] about the explanation of [[Surah]] [[Al-Fatiha]]. In this [[book]], he interpreted the [[ideology]] of Wahdat al-wujud for the first time in the most comprehensive way.{{citation needed|reason=The existence of this work is disputed first. if this work exists a reliable interpretation must also be mentioned. The text should be written ink the conductive genus and not indicative, because it is not clear.|date=August 2016}} After that, the mystical thinker and theologian [[Abu Saeed Mubarak Makhzoomi]] discussed this concept in his book called Tohfa Mursala.<ref>{{cite book | url = http://www.yanabi.com/index.php?/topic/376532-tohfa-mursala-sharif-lectures-by-khawaja-ghulam-qutab-din-faridi-dba/ | title = Tohfa Mursala by Abu Saeed Mubarak Makhzoomi | publisher = yanabi.com | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160518214710/http://www.yanabi.com/index.php?%2Ftopic%2F376532-tohfa-mursala-sharif-lectures-by-khawaja-ghulam-qutab-din-faridi-dba%2F | archivedate = 18 May 2016 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> An [[Andalusia]]n Sufi saint [[Ibn Sabin]]<ref>[[Seyyed Hossein Nasr|S.H. Nasr]] (2006), ''Islamic Philosophy from Its Origin to the Present: Philosophy in the Land of Prophecy'', State University of New York Press, p. 156</ref> is also known to employ this term in his writings. But the [[Sufi]] [[saint]] who is most characterized in discussing the ideology of Sufi metaphysics in deepest details is [[Ibn Arabi]].<ref name="muslimphilosophy1">[http://www.muslimphilosophy.com/ip/rep/H022 Ibn al-'Arabi, Muhyi al-Din (1164–1240)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> He employs the term wujud to refer to God as the Necessary [[Being]]. He also attributes the term to everything other than God, but he insists that wujud does not belong to the things found in the [[cosmos]] in any real sense. Rather, the things borrow wujud from [[God]], much as the [[earth]] borrow light from the [[sun]]. The issue is how wujūd can rightfully be attributed to the things, also called "[[entity|entities]]" (aʿyān). From the perspective of [[tanzih]], [[Ibn Arabi]] declares that wujūd belongs to [[God]] alone, and, in his famous phrase, the things "have never smelt a whiff of wujud." From the point of view of [[tasbih]], he affirms that all things are wujūd's self-disclosure ([[tajalli]]) or self-manifestation (ẓohur). In sum, all things are "He/not He" (howa/lāhowa), which is to say that they are both God and other than God, both wujud and other than wujud.<ref name=autogenerated1>Imaginal worlds, William Chiittick (1994), pg.53</ref> In his book Fasus –al-Hikam,<ref>{{cite book|author=Ibn Arabi|url=http://www.sufi.ir/books/download/english/ibn-arabi-en/fusus-al-hikam-en.pdf|title=Fasus-al-Hikam}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author= Ibn-e-Arabi|url=https://bewley.virtualave.net/fusus.html|title=Fasus-al-Hikam}}</ref> Ibn-e-Arabi states that " wujūd is the unknowable and inaccessible ground of everything that exists. God alone is true wujūd, while all things dwell in nonexistence, so also wujūd alone is nondelimited (muṭlaq), while everything else is constrained, confined, and constricted. Wujūd is the absolute, infinite, nondelimited reality of God, while all others remain relative, finite, and delimited".
[[Ibn Arabi]]’s doctrine of wahdat ul wujud focuses on the esoteric ([[Batin (Islam)|batin]]) reality of creatures instead of exoteric ([[Zahir (Islam)|zahir]]) dimension of reality. Therefore he interprets that wujud is one and unique reality from which all reality derives. The external world of sensible objects is but a fleeting shadow of the Real (al- Haq), God . God alone is the all embracing and [[eternity|eternal]] reality. Whatever exists is the shadow([[tajalli]]) of the Real and is not independent of God. This is summed up in [[Ibn Arabi]]’s own words. " [[Glory (religion)|Glory]] to Him who created all things, being Himself their very [[essence]](ainuha)"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.muslimphilosophy.com/hmp/chp20.doc|title=A History of Muslim Philosophy, pg. 409.}}</ref>
To call wujud or Real Being "one" is to speak of the unity of the Essence. In other terms, it is to say that Being—Light in itself—is nondelimited (mutlaq), that is, [[infinity|infinite]] and [[absolute (philosophy)|absolute]], undefined and indefinable, indistinct and indistinguishable. In contrast, everything other than Being—every existent thing (mawjûd)—is [[distinction (philosophy)|distinct]], [[defined]], and limited(muqayyad). The Real is incomparable and transcendent, but it discloses itself (tajallî) in all things, so it is also similar and immanent. It possesses such utter nondelimitation that it is not delimited by nondelimitation. "God possesses Nondelimited Being, but no delimitation prevents Him from delimitation. On the contrary, He possesses all delimitations, so He is nondelimited delimitation" <ref name=autogenerated1 /><ref>{{cite web|url= http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/ibn-arabi/|title= (Ibn ‘Arabî, al-Futûhât}}</ref> On the highest level, wujūd is the absolute and nondelimited reality of God, the "Necessary Being" (wājib al-wujūd) that cannot not exist. In this sense, wujūd designates the Essence of God or of the Real (dhāt al-ḥaqq), the only reality that is real in every respect. On lower levels, wujūd is the underlying substance of "everything other than God" (māsiwāAllāh)—which is how [[Ibn Arabi]] and others define the "cosmos" or "universe" (al-ʿālam). Hence, in a secondary meaning, the term wujūd is used as shorthand to refer to the whole [[cosmos]], to everything that exists. It can also be employed to refer to the existence of each and every thing that is found in the [[universe]].<ref name=autogenerated2>Imaginal worlds, William Chiittick(1994), pg.15</ref>
God's 'names' or '[[Property (philosophy)|attributes]]', on the other hand, are the relationships which can be discerned between the [[Essence]] and the [[cosmos]]. They are known to God because he knows every object of knowledge, but they are not existent entities or ontological qualities, for this would imply plurality in the godhead.<ref name="muslimphilosophy1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/ibn-arabi/#WahAlWu|title=Names and Relations}}</ref> Ibn 'Arabî used the term "effusion" (fayd) to denote the act of creation. His writings contain expressions which show different stages of creation, a distinction merely logical and not actual. The following gives details about his vision of creation in three stages: the Most Holy Effusion (al-fayd al-aqdas), the Holy Effusion (al-fayd al-muqaddas) and the Perpetual Effusion (al-fayd al-mustamirr).<ref name=autogenerated3>[http://www.ibnarabisociety.org/articles/unityofbeing.html Souad Hakim – Unity of Being in Ibn 'Arabî<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Waḥdat al-wujūd spread through the teachings of the [[Sufi]]s like Qunyawi, Jandi, Tilimsani, Qayshari, Jami etc.<ref name=autogenerated4>Seyyed Hossein Nasr, Islamic Philosophy from Its Origin to the Present(2006), pg76</ref>
The noted scholar [[Muhibullah Allahabadi]] strongly supported the doctrine.<ref>{{cite book|last=Hadi|first=Nabi|title=Dictionary of Indo-Persian Literature|page=427 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qjJmzdJFOHwC&pg=PA427|accessdate=2014-11-10|year=1995|publisher=Abhinav Publications|isbn=978-81-7017-311-3|chapter=MuhhibbullahIlahabadi, Shaikh}}</ref>
[[Sachal Sarmast]] and [[Bulleh Shah]] two Sufi poets from [[India]], were also ardent followers of Waḥdat al-wujūd. It is also associated with the ''Hamah Ust'' ([[Persian Language|Persian]] meaning "He is the only one") philosophy in South Asia.
==Tashkīk== Tashkīk or gradation<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3WwAAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA93&dq=tashkik&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCcQ6AEwAGoVChMIh4-Oo7e3yAIVT81jCh2-sQdU#v=onepage&q=tashkik&f=false|title=tashkik}}</ref> is closely associated with Sadrian interpretation<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.muslimphilosophy.com/ip/rep/H027.html|title=Tashkik al Wujud}}</ref> of waḥdat al-wujūd. According to this school, the reality and [[existence]] are identical which means existence is one but graded in intensity. This methodology was given a name of tashkik al-wujud and it thus explains that there is gradation of existence that stand in a vast hierarchical chain of being (marāṭib al-wujūd) from floor (farsh) to divine throne (ʿarsh), but the wujūd of each existent ''māhīyya'' is nothing but a grade of the single reality of wujūd whose source is God, the absolute being (al-wujūd al-mutlaq). What differentiates the wujūd of different existents is nothing but wujūd in different degrees of strength and weakness. The universe is nothing but different degrees of strengths and weaknesses of wujūd, ranging from intense degree of wujūd of arch-angelic realities, to the dim wujūd of lowly dust from which Adam was made.<ref>Seyyed Hossein Nasr, Islamic Philosophy from Its Origin to the Present, pg 78</ref>
==Criticism of the concept== Sufi metaphysics has been a subject to criticism by most non-Sufis; in [[Al-Andalus]], where most of the Muslim scholars were either [[Zahiri]]tes or [[Maliki]]tes preferring the [[Ash'ari]]te [[Islamic theology|creed]], Sufi metaphysics was considered blasphemy and its practitioners blacklisted.<ref name=arabi169>Alexander D. Knysh, ''Ibn Arabi in the Later Islamic Tradition''. Pg. 169. [[State University of New York Press]]: [[Albany, New York|Albany]], 1999.</ref> Followers of the Ash'arite creed in the east were often suspicious of Sufism as well, most often citing Sufi metaphysics as well.<ref name=arabi169/>
===Criticism from within Sufism=== Some [[Sufi]]s, such as [[Ahmad Sirhindi]], have criticised wahdat-al-wujud. Ahmad Sirhindi wrote about the sayings that universe has no existence of its own and is a shadow of the existence of the necessary being. He also wrote that one should discern the existence of universe from the absolute and that the absolute does not exist because of existence but because of his essence.<ref>MaktoobatRabbaniyah</ref>
===Response to criticism=== [[Pir Meher Ali Shah]] and [[Syed Waheed Ashraf]] have countered that the two concepts differ in that wahdat-al-wujud states that God and the universe aren't identical.<ref>TehqiqulHaq fi KalamatulHaq a book by [[Meher Ali Shah|PirMeher Ali Shah]]</ref><ref>'Tasawwuf' a book in Urdu by [[Syed Waheed Ashraf]]</ref> They hold real existence to be for God only and the universe to have no existence on its own.
==Waḥdat asḥ-Shuhūd== Waḥdat asḥ-Shuhūd (or ''wah-dat-ul-shuhud'', ''wahdat-ul-shuhud,'' or ''wahdatulshuhud'') has often been translated into English as '''Apparentism'''. In Arabic it literally means "unity of witness", "unity of perception", "unity of appearance" or "oneness of manifestation".
Out of those who opposed the doctrine of waḥdat al-wujūd, there were those who substituted the pole of subject for the object, formulating the doctrine of Waḥdat asḥ-Shuhūd. This school was formulated by ʿAlāʾ ad-DawlahSimnānī, was to attract many followers in India, including [[Ahmed Sirhindi]] who provided some of the most widely accepted formulations of this doctrine in the Indian sub-continent.<ref name=autogenerated4 /><ref>'Tasawwuf' book in Urdu by Syed Waheed Ashraf</ref>
According to Ahmed Sirhindi's doctrine, any experience of unity between God and the created world is purely subjective and occurs only in the mind of the believer; it has no objective counterpart in the real world. The former position, Shaykh Ahmad felt, led to pantheism, which was contrary to the tenets of Sunni Islam.{{Citation needed|date=September 2007}} He held that God and creation are not identical; rather, the latter is a shadow or reflection of the Divines Name and Attributes when they are reflected in the mirrors of their opposite non-beings (aʿdām al-mutaqābilah).{{Citation needed|date=September 2007}}[[Abu Hafs Umar al-Suhrawardi]] and [[Abd-al-karim Jili]] were also proponents of apparent-ism.
==Al-Wujūd Al-Munbasiṭ (Self-unfolding Being)== [[Shah Waliullah Dehlawi]] tried to reconcile the two (apparently) contradictory doctrines of waḥdat al-wujūd (unity of being) of [[Ibn Arabi]] and waḥdat ash-shuhūd (unity in conscience) of Shaykh Ahmad Sirhindi. Shah Waliullah neatly resolved the conflict, calling these differences 'verbal controversies' which have come about because of ambiguous language. If we leave, he says, all the metaphors and similes used for the expression of ideas aside, the apparently opposite views of the two metaphysicians will agree. The positive result of Shah Wali Allah's reconciliatory efforts was twofold: it brought about harmony between the two opposing groups of meta-physicians, and it also legitimized the doctrine of waḥdat al-wujūd among the mutakallimun (theologians), who previously had not been ready to accept it.
In his books Lamahat and Sata'at, he discusses stages of being, the perceptive faculty, the relation of the abstract with the universe, the universal soul and the souls of man, after death, essence, miracles, the scope of man, the soul of the perfect, universal order, source of manifestation, and the transformation of mystics from quality to quality. He also demonstrated that the long-standing assumption that Sufi doctrine was divided between Apparentism and Unity of Being was a difference of expression alone, the latter doctrine being seen as merely a less-advanced stage of projection.<ref>[http://www.muslimphilosophy.com/ip/rep/H045 Shah Wali Allah (Qutb al-Din Ahmad al-Rahim) (1703–62)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
In his opinion this whole universe has also self (nafs) as an individual person has a self, which is called the Universal Soul (an-nafs al-kullīyyah). The multiplicity of the whole universe has originated from it. When [[Ibn Arabi]] says that everything is God, he thereby means the Universal Soul. This Universal Soul, or the Self-unfolding Being (al-wujūd-al-munbasiṭ), subsists by itself. This existence pervades the whole universe, both the substance and the accident, and accepts the form of everything. It is both immanent and transcendental. Beyond this existence (al-wujūd al-munbasiṭ : Universal Soul) towards the original existence (God) none has access to. In other words, man's progress ends with the Universal Soul or the Self-unfolding Being. He cannot move a step further. The Universal Soul and God are so intermingled that the former is often taken for the latter."
As for the question of the relation that this existence (al-wujūd al-munbasiṭ) has with the essence of God itself. This relation is, however, known only in its reality (anniyyah : I-ness); its quality is unknown and can never be known. Thus when [[Ibn Arabi]] says that the realities of the existing things are the names and the attributes of the Universal Soul (Self-unfolding Being) in the stage of knowledge (fīmarṭabat al-ʿilm, in the Divine Consciousness) or when Imam Rabbani asserts that the realities of existing objects are sheer nothingness on which the lights of the names and attributes of the Universal Soul (al-wujūd al-munbasiṭ) are reflected is exactly the same thing. The difference in their language is so little that it needs no consideration.<ref>G. N. Jalbani, ''The Teachings of Shah Waliyullah of Delhi'', pg98</ref>
== Waḥdat al-Maqṣūd == [[Sultan Bahoo]] first introduced the concept of 'waḥdat al-maqṣūd,' the 'intention of Unity' or the 'necessity of unity.' Sultan Bahoo did not sufficiently elaborate on this idea, focusing his interest and attention towards the concept of 'fanāʾ fi-llāh, baqāʾbillāh' ([[Annihilation]] in God, Lasting with God). He was the only [[Sufi]] scholar to establish the concept of lasting forever with [[Allah]] by ceasing, or annihilating one's self in [[Allah]].

[[Syracuse University]]|appointer=[[Peter Salovey]]|image=Tamar Gendler.jpg}} '''Tamar Szabó Gendler''' (born December 20, 1965) is the Dean of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences at Yale{{Cite web|title = Salovey names new deans|url = http://yaledailynews.com/blog/2014/05/21/salovey-names-new-deans/|website = |accessdate = 2015-11-12|publisher = Yale Daily News|last = Lloyd-Thomas|first = Matthew|date = May 21, 2015}}{{Cite web|title = Faculty of Arts and Sciences|url = http://fas.yale.edu/|website = |accessdate = 2015-11-12}} as well as the [[Vincent Scully|Vincent J. Scully]] Professor of Philosophy and a Professor of Psychology and Cognitive Sciences at [[Yale University]]. Her academic research focuses on issues in [[philosophical psychology]], [[epistemology]], [[metaphysics]], and areas related to [[philosophical methodology]]. == Biography == === Education and employment === Gendler was born in 1965 in [[Princeton, New Jersey]] to Mary and [[Everett Gendler]], a [[Conservative Judaism|Conservative]] rabbi. She grew up in [[Andover, Massachusetts]], where she attended the Andover public schools and then [[Phillips Academy|Phillips Academy Andover]].{{cite magazine |title=Class Notes |magazine=Andover Bulletin |page=91 |url=http://www.alumniconnections.com/olc/pub/PAA/files/Summer08ClassNotes.pdf |format=PDF |date=Summer 2008 |accessdate=2010-05-27}} As an undergraduate, she studied at [[Yale University]], where she was a championship debater in the [[American Parliamentary Debate Association]] and a member of [[Manuscript Society]].{{cite web|url=http://www.yaledebate.org/reunion/schedule.php |title=YDA Alumni Reunion |publisher=Yaledebate.org |date= |accessdate=2010-05-27 |dead-url=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100328125842/http://www.yaledebate.org/reunion/schedule.php |archivedate=March 28, 2010 }} She graduated ''summa cum laude'' in 1987 with Distinction in Humanities and Math & Philosophy. After graduating from college, she worked for several years as an assistant to [[Linda Darling-Hammond]] at the RAND Corporation’s education policy division in Washington, DC.{{cite web|url=https://www.rand.org/pubs/authors/g/gendler_tamar.html |title=Reports & Bookstore | Authors | G | Tamar Gendler |publisher=RAND |date= |accessdate=2010-05-27}} In 1996, she earned her philosophy [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] at Harvard University, with [[Robert Nozick]], [[Derek Parfit]] and [[Hilary Putnam]] as her advisors.{{cite web|url=http://pantheon.yale.edu/~tgendler/TamarGendlerAbout.htm |title=Tamar Gendler About |publisher=Pantheon.yale.edu |date=2009-10-19 |accessdate=2010-05-27}} Gendler taught philosophy at [[Yale University]] (1996–97), [[Syracuse University]] (1997–2003) and [[Cornell University]] (2003–06), before returning to Yale in 2006 as Professor of Philosophy and Chair of the Yale University [[Cognitive Science]] Program (2006–2010).{{cite news |last= Marsden |first=Jessica |url=http://yaledailynews.com/blog/2006/03/02/philosophy-takes-steps-to-rebuild/ |title=Philosophy takes steps to rebuild |newspaper=Yale Daily News |date=2 March 2006 |accessdate=21 April 2014}} On July 1, 2010, she became Chair of the Yale University Department of Philosophy, becoming the first woman to hold that position in the department’s history and the first female graduate of [[Yale College]] to chair a Yale Department. She held the position until 2013, when she was appointed as Deputy Provost for Humanities and Initiatives.{{cite web |website=Office of the Provost |title=Gendler appointed deputy provost for the humanities and initiatives |publisher=Yale University |url=http://provost.yale.edu/news/gendler-appointed-deputy-provost-humanities-and-initiatives |accessdate=20 April 2014}} Since July 2014, Gendler served as the inaugural Dean of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences at Yale.http://fas.yale.edu/news/new-deans-lead-yale-college-graduate-school-and-first-time-fas/http://yaledailynews.com/blog/2014/05/21/salovey-names-new-deans/ Gendler is married to Zoltan Gendler Szabo, a philosopher and linguist who is also a professor at Yale University.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/18/style/weddings-tamar-gendler-zoltan-szabo.html |title=WEDDINGS; Tamar Gendler, Zoltan Szabo |newspaper=New York Times |date=1995-06-18 |accessdate=2010-05-27}}{{cite web |url=http://www.yaledailynews.com/news/university-news/2006/02/28/philosophy-recruits-five-new-profs/ |title=Philosophy recruits five new profs |publisher=Yale Daily News |date=2006-02-28 |accessdate=2010-05-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130209194349/http://www.yaledailynews.com/news/university-news/2006/02/28/philosophy-recruits-five-new-profs/ |archivedate=2013-02-09 |df= }} They have two children. === Honors and professional accomplishments === Gendler has held Fellowships from the [[Andrew W. Mellon Foundation]] Fellowship Program in the Humanities, the [[National Science Foundation]], the [[American Council of Learned Societies]]/Ryskamp Fellowship Program,{{cite web|url=http://www.acls.org/uploadedFiles/Publications/AR/Ar05-07_Web.pdf |title=ACLS Annual Report 2005-2007 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2010-05-27}} the Collegium Budapest Institute for Advanced Studies, and the Mellon New Directions Program.{{cite web |title=New Directions Fellowships |publisher=The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation |url=http://www.mellon.org/grant_programs/programs/higher-education-and-scholarship/new-direction-fellowships |accessdate=21 April 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100110100434/http://www.mellon.org/grant_programs/programs/higher-education-and-scholarship/new-direction-fellowships |archivedate=10 January 2010 |df= }} In 2012, she was appointed as the [[Vincent J. Scully]] [[Professor#Tenured and tenure-track positions|Professor]] of [[Philosophy]] at Yale.{{cite web |title= Tamar Gendler appointed the Vincent J. Scully Professor |publisher=Yale News |url=http://news.yale.edu/2012/12/04/tamar-gendler-appointed-vincent-j-scully-professor |accessdate=20 April 2014}} In 2013, she was awarded the Yale College-Sidonie Miskimin Clauss ’75 Prize for Excellence in Teaching in the Humanities.{{cite web |url=http://teaching-spotlight.yale.edu/awards-teaching-excellence/yale-college-teaching-prizes |title= Yale College Teaching Prizes 2013 |publisher=Yale College |date=2013 |accessdate=21 April 2014}} She is the author of ''Thought Experiments: On the Powers and Limits of Imaginary Cases'' (Routledge, 2000){{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/Thought-Experiment-Imaginary-Studies-Philosophy/dp/081533656X|title=Thought Experiment: On the Powers and Limits of Imaginary Cases|last=Gendler|first=Tamar Szabo|date=2000-11-02|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9780815336563|edition= 1st|location=New York|language=English}} and ''Intuition, Imagination and Philosophical Methodology'' (Oxford, 2010),{{Cite journal|date=2010-12-01|title=Intuition, Imagination, and Philosophical Methodology - Oxford Scholarship|url=http://www.oxfordscholarship.com/view/10.1093/acprof:oso/9780199589760.001.0001/acprof-9780199589760|language=en|doi=10.1093/acprof:oso/9780199589760.001.0001/acprof-9780199589760}} and editor or co-editor of ''The Elements of Philosophy'' (Oxford 2008),{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/The-Elements-Philosophy-Readings-Present/dp/0195335422|title=The Elements of Philosophy: Readings from Past and Present|last=results|first=search|date=2007-12-26|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780195335422|editor-last=Gendler|editor-first=Tamar Szabo|edition= 1st|location=New York|language=English|editor-last2=Siegel|editor-first2=Susanna}} ''Perceptual Experience'' (Oxford, 2006),{{Cite journal|date=2006-01-19|title=Perceptual Experience - Oxford Scholarship|url=http://www.oxfordscholarship.com/view/10.1093/acprof:oso/9780199289769.001.0001/acprof-9780199289769|language=en|doi=10.1093/acprof:oso/9780199289769.001.0001/acprof-9780199289769}} ''Conceivability and Possibility'' (Oxford 2002). She is also co-editor of the journal ''Oxford Studies in Epistemology''{{Cite book|url=https://global.oup.com/academic/product/oxford-studies-in-epistemology-9780199237067?cc=ca&lang=en&|title=Oxford Studies in Epistemology: Volume 2|date=2008|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199237067|series=Oxford Studies in Epistemology|location=Oxford, New York}} ''and The Oxford Handbook of Philosophical Methodology''.{{Cite book|url=https://global.oup.com/academic/product/the-oxford-handbook-of-philosophical-methodology-9780199668779?cc=ca&lang=en&|title=The Oxford Handbook of Philosophical Methodology|date=2016-07-19|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199668779|series=Oxford Handbooks|location=Oxford, New York}} Her philosophical articles have appeared in journals such as the [[Journal of Philosophy]], [[Mind]], [[Philosophical Perspectives]], [[Mind & Language]], [[Midwest Studies in Philosophy]], [[Philosophical Studies]], and [[The Philosophical Quarterly]]. Her 2008 essay “Alief and Belief” was selected by the ''Philosopher’s Annual'' as one of the 10 best articles published in philosophy in 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.philosophersannual.org/ |title=Philosopher's Annual |publisher=Philosophersannual.org |date= |accessdate=2010-05-27}} She also lectures occasionally for non-professional audiences as a professor with [[One Day University]]{{cite web|url=http://www.onedayu.com/ |title=One Day University | Live Classes, Adult Education & Local Classes |publisher=Onedayu.com |date= |accessdate=2010-05-27}} and as a diavlogger on [[bloggingheads.tv]] where she runs [http://bloggingheads.tv/programs/mind-report The Mind Report] with her colleagues [[Laurie R. Santos]], [[Paul Bloom (psychologist)|Paul Bloom]] and [[Joshua Knobe]].{{cite web|url=http://bloggingheads.tv/ |title=Bloggingheads.tv |publisher=Bloggingheads.tv |date= |accessdate=2010-05-27}} She also serves on the Board of Advisors of the Marc Sanders Foundation,http://www.marcsandersfoundation.org/about/whos-who/ which awards prizes for outstanding work in [[philosophy]]. On September 3, 2013, Gendler delivered the Keynote address to Yale freshmen during the class of 2017 matriculation ceremony. Her topic was "Keeping inconsistency in your pockets."{{Cite news|url=https://news.yale.edu/2013/09/03/freshmen-keeping-inconsistency-your-pockets|title=To freshmen: Keeping inconsistency in your pockets|date=2013-09-03|work=YaleNews|access-date=2018-05-15|language=en}} She is best known for her work on [[thought experiments]],{{cite web|url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/thought-experiment/ |title=Thought Experiments (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy) |publisher=Plato.stanford.edu |date= |accessdate=2010-05-27}} [[imagination]]—particularly on the phenomenon of [[Aesthetic emotions|imaginative resistance]]{{cite web|url=http://philpapers.org/rec/GENTPO |title=Tamar Szabó Gendler, The puzzle of imaginative resistance |publisher=PhilPapers |date=2009-01-27 |accessdate=2010-05-27}}—and for coining the term [[Alief (belief)|alief]].{{cite web|url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/introspection/ |title=Introspection (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy) |publisher=Plato.stanford.edu |date=2010-02-02 |accessdate=2010-05-27}} == Bibliography == * ''The Oxford Handbook of Philosophical Methodology''. {{Infobox book | <!-- See [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Novels]] or [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Books]] --> | name = The Rules of Sociological Method | title_orig = Les règles de la méthode sociologique | translator = | image = The Rules of the Sociological Method.jpg | caption = Cover of the 1919 French edition | author = [[Émile Durkheim]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = France | language = French | series = | subject = [[Sociology]] | genre = | publisher = | release_date = 1895 | english_release_date = | media_type = Print | pages = | isbn = | oclc= | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''The Rules of Sociological Method''''' ({{lang-fr|Les Règles de la Méthode Sociologique}}) is a book by [[Émile Durkheim]], first published in 1895. It is recognized as being the direct result of Durkheim's own project of establishing [[sociology]] as a [[positivist]] [[social science]].<ref name="Popolo2011"/><ref name="Reed2006">{{cite book|author=Kate Reed|title=New Directions in Social Theory: Race, Gender and the Canon|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VY_GOuxcL4AC&pg=PA27|accessdate=17 March 2011|year=2006|publisher=SAGE|isbn=978-0-7619-4270-2|pages=27–}}</ref> Durkheim is seen as one of the fathers of sociology,<ref name="BerkmanKawachi2000">{{cite book|author1=Lisa F. Berkman|author2=Ichirō Kawachi|title=Social Epidemiology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i0qWxy5-X1gC&pg=PA138|accessdate=17 March 2011|year=2000|publisher=Oxford University Press US|isbn=978-0-19-508331-6|pages=138–}}</ref> and this work, his [[manifesto]] of sociology.<ref name="Durkheim1982">{{cite book|author=Émile Durkheim|title=The Rules of Sociological Method|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dM01B9O6s8YC&pg=PA2|accessdate=17 March 2011|year=1982|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=978-0-02-907940-9|pages=2–}}</ref> Durkheim distinguishes sociology from other sciences and justifies his rationale.<ref name="Popolo2011"/> Sociology is the science of [[social facts]]. Durkheim suggests two central theses, without which sociology would not be a science:
# It must have a specific object of study. Unlike [[philosophy]] or [[psychology]], sociology's proper object of study are social facts. # It must respect and apply a recognized [[objectivity (science)|objective]] [[scientific method]], bringing it as close as possible to the other [[exact science]]s. This method must at all cost avoid [[prejudice]] and [[subjectivism|subjective]] judgment.<ref name="Leavy2008">{{cite book|author=[[Patricia Leavy]]|title=Method Meets Art: Arts-based Research Practice|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=e7H6SejkvuEC&pg=PA5|accessdate=17 March 2011|date=30 July 2008|publisher=Guilford Press|isbn=978-1-59385-259-7|pages=5–}}</ref>
This book was one of the defining books for the new science of [[sociology]].<ref name="Noreck">{{cite book|author=Ferreol & Noreck|title=Introduction to Sociology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vbo0uvmAqzkC&pg=PA12|accessdate=17 March 2011|publisher=PHI Learning Pvt. Ltd.|isbn=978-81-203-3940-8|pages=12–}}</ref> Durkheim's argument that social sciences should be approached with the same rigorous [[scientific method]] as used in [[natural sciences]] was seen as revolutionary for the time.<ref name="Noreck"/>
''The Rules'' is seen as an important text in sociology and is a popular book on [[sociological theory]] courses. The book's meaning is still being debated by sociologists.<ref name="Pickering2001">{{cite book|author=W. S. F. Pickering|title=Emile Durkheim: Critical Assessments of Leading Sociologists|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gGx7WFhjRiIC&pg=PA232|accessdate=17 March 2011|year=2001|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-0-415-20562-7|pages=232–}}</ref><ref name="HillHoecker-Drysdale2002">{{cite book|author1=Michael R. Hill|author2=Susan Hoecker-Drysdale|title=Harriet Martineau: Theoretical and Methodological Perspectives|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qyzyUpMfh24C&pg=PA80|accessdate=17 March 2011|date=15 November 2002|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-0-415-94528-8|pages=80–}}</ref>
==Sociology as the study of social facts== Durkheim's concern is to establish sociology as a science.<ref name="Popolo2011">{{cite book|author=Damian Popolo|title=A New Science of International Relations: Modernity, Complexity and the Kosovo Conflict|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vMALg_p5zHsC&pg=PA97|accessdate=17 March 2011|date=16 January 2011|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|isbn=978-1-4094-1226-7|pages=97–}}</ref> Arguing for a place for sociology among other sciences, he wrote, "Sociology is, then, not an auxiliary of any other science; it is itself a distinct and autonomous science."<ref name="BrintonNee2001">{{cite book|author1=Mary C. Brinton|author2=Victor Nee|title=The New Institutionalism in Sociology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=71e_jsQpzg0C&pg=PR11|accessdate=17 March 2011|year=2001|publisher=Stanford University Press|isbn=978-0-8047-4276-4|pages=11–}}</ref> To give sociology a place in the academic world and to ensure that it is a legitimate science, it must have an object that is clear and distinct from philosophy or psychology. He argued, "There is in every society a certain group of phenomena which may be differentiated from those studied by the other natural sciences."<ref>{{cite book|author1=Scott Appelrouth|author2=Laura Desfor Edles|title=Classical and Contemporary Sociological Theory: Text and Readings|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EUQT47IqVdgC&pg=PA95|accessdate=17 March 2011|date=26 September 2007|publisher=Pine Forge Press|isbn=978-0-7619-2793-8|pages=95–}}</ref>
With regards to social facts, Durkheim defined them as follows: {{quote|A social fact is every way of acting, fixed or not, capable of exercising on the individual an external constraint; or again, every way of acting which is general throughout a given society, while at the same time existing in its own right independent of its individual manifestations.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Scott Appelrouth|author2=Laura Desfor Edles|title=Classical and Contemporary sociological Theory: Text and Readings|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EUQT47IqVdgC&pg=PA99|accessdate=17 March 2011|date=26 September 2007|publisher=Pine Forge Press|isbn=978-0-7619-2793-8|pages=99–}}</ref>}}
One of the book's challenges is in showing how individual and seemingly chaotic decisions are in fact a result of a larger, more structured system, the pattern being held together by "social facts".<ref name="BerkmanKawachi2000"/>
The definition of social facts illustrates the [[holistic]] paradigm in which Durkheim's social facts are defined by two main features: they are external to and coercive to individuals.<ref name="Reed2006"/> They not only represent behaviour but also the rules that govern behaviour and give it meaning.<ref name="Collin2002">{{cite book|author=Finn Collin|title=Social Reality|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XaHXD5g8EAoC&pg=PA217|accessdate=17 March 2011|date=1 January 2002|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-0-203-04792-7|pages=217–}}</ref> Social facts have been not only accepted by, but have been adopted by society as rules to which they choose to follow.<ref name="Durkheim1982" /> Law, language, morality and marriage are all examples of ideals formed through individual thought that have manifested into these concrete institutions which we must now abide by.<ref name="Preston1996">{{cite book|author=Peter Wallace Preston|title=Development Theory: An Introduction|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_B1_qN8W-9AC&pg=PA87|accessdate=17 March 2011|year=1996|publisher=Wiley-Blackwell|isbn=978-0-631-19555-9|pages=87–}}</ref> Social facts can be constraining: if individuals do not do act as they dictate, they may face social penalties.<ref name="Preston1996"/> The binding nature of social facts is often implicit, because the rules of society are internalized by individuals in the process of education and socialization.<ref name="Preston1996"/>
Durkheim distinguished two types of social facts: normal social facts – which, within a society, occur regularly and most often – and pathological social facts – which are much less common.
==Principles of sociology== According to Durkheim, sociologists, without preconceptions and prejudices, must study social facts as real, objective phenomena.<ref name="Durkheim1982"/> Durkheim wrote, "The first and most fundamental rule is: Consider social facts as things."<ref name="Hollis1994">{{cite book|author=Martin Hollis|title=The Philosophy of Social Science: An Introduction|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1JcsHEm9CLgC&pg=PA99|accessdate=17 March 2011|year=1994|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-44780-5|pages=99–}}</ref> This implies that sociology must respect and apply a recognized objective, scientific method, bringing it as close as possible to the other exact sciences.<ref name="Durkheim1982"/> This method must at all cost avoid prejudice and subjective judgment.<ref name="Durkheim1982"/>
Furthermore Durkheim talks about social phenomena and how they must be studied. Durkheim wrote: {{quote|Social phenomena must be considered in themselves, detached from the conscious beings who form their own mental representations of them. They must be studied from the outside, as external things, because it is in this guise that they present themselves to us<ref>''The Rules of Sociological Method''</ref>}}
== See also == {{Portal|Sociology}} * ''[[A General View of Positivism]]'' * [[Structural functionalism]]

'''William Calvert Kneale''' (22 June 1906 – 24 June 1990) was an [[England|English]] [[logician]] best known for his 1962 book ''The Development of Logic'', a history of logic from its beginnings in [[Ancient Greece]] written with his wife [[Martha Kneale|Martha]]. Kneale was also known as a [[Philosophy of science|philosopher of science]] and the author of a book on [[probability]] and [[inductive reasoning|induction]]. Educated at the Liverpool Institute High School for boys, he later became a fellow of [[Exeter College, Oxford]], and in 1960 succeeded to the [[White's Professor of Moral Philosophy]] previously occupied by the linguistic philosopher [[J. L. Austin]]. He retired in 1966.
== Life and work ==
Kneale's interest in the [[history of logic]] began in the 1940s. The focus of much of Kneale's early work was the legacy of the work of the 19th century logician [[George Boole]]. His first major publication in the history of logic was his paper "Boole and the Revival of Logic," published in the philosophy journal [[Mind_(journal)| Mind]] in 1948. He was also the author of a number of papers in [[Philosophical logic]], particularly on the nature of [[truth]] for [[natural language]]s, and the role that linguistic concepts play in the treatment of logical [[paradoxes]].
Kneale worked on his great history of logic from 1947 to 1957 together with his wife Martha (who was responsible for the chapters on the ancient Greeks). The result was the 800-page ''The Development of Logic'', first published in 1962, which went through five impressions before going into a second, paperback, edition in 1984.
The 'History' is commonly referred to in the academic world simply as "Kneale and Kneale". It was the only major history of logic available in English in the mid-twentieth century, and the first major history of logic in English since ''The Development of Symbolic Logic'' published in 1906 by [[A.T. Shearman]]. The treatise has been a standard work in the history of logic for decades.
In 1938 he married [[Martha Kneale|Martha Hurst]]; they had two children, George (born 1942) and [[Jane Heal|Jane (married name Heal)]]; born 1946).
== References ==
* Thomas Drucker and Irving H. Anellis, [http://projecteuclid.org/DPubS/Repository/1.0/Disseminate?handle=euclid.rml/1204834969&view=body&content-type=pdf_1 'William Kneale' memorial notice], ''Modern Logic'' Volume 3, Number 2 (1993), 158–161.

{{Infobox philosopher | region = [[Western philosophy]] | era = [[20th-century philosophy]] | image = | caption = | name = Wolfgang Stegmüller | birth_date = {{Birth date|1923|6|3|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Natters]], [[First Republic of Austria|Austria]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1991|6|11|1923|6|3|df=y}} | death_place = [[Munich]], [[Germany]] | alma_mater = [[University of Innsbruck]] | school_tradition = [[Analytic philosophy]]
[[Structuralism (philosophy of science)|Scientific structuralism]] | main_interests = [[Philosophy of science]] | influences = [[W. V. O. Quine]], [[Joseph D. Sneed]], [[Thomas S. Kuhn]] | influenced = {{Interlanguage link multi|Franz von Kutschera|de}}, {{Interlanguage link multi|Lorenz Bruno Puntel|de}} | notable_ideas = }} '''Wolfgang Stegmüller''' ({{IPA-de|ˈʃteːgˌmʏlɐ|lang}}; June 3, 1923 – June 11, 1991), was a German-Austrian philosopher with important contributions in [[philosophy of science]] and in [[analytic philosophy]]. ==Biography== W. Stegmüller studied [[economics]] and [[philosophy]] at the [[University of Innsbruck]]. In 1944 he graduated as "Diplom-Volkswirt" and one year later he obtained a PhD in economics. Also at the University of Innsbruck he obtained in 1947 a PhD in philosophy. In 1949 he [[Habilitation|habilitated]] with the thesis "Sein, Wahrheit und Wert in der heutigen Philosophie". After a stay of one year at the University of Oxford in 1954 he returned to the University of Innsbruck where he was appointed as associate professor for philosophy in 1956. After stays as visiting professor at the Universities of Kiel and Bonn he received a call from the Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich. Here in 1958 he was appointed professor for philosophy, logic, and philosophy of sciences and became director of the "Seminar II". Except for two stays at as a visiting professor in 1962/63 and 1964 at the University of Pennsylvania he remained in Munich and ran there a center for [[analytical philosophy]] until his retirement in 1990. From 1977 to 1979 he also was dean of the faculty for philosophy, philosophy of science, and statistics. Stegmüller was from 1966 on a corresponding member of the [[Austrian Academy of Sciences]] and from 1967 on a member of the [[Bavarian Academy of Sciences and Humanities]]. 1972 he became a member of the French [[Institut International de Philosophie]], located in Paris. He also was a member of the [[International Academy of Science, Munich]] founded in 1980.[http://www.ias-icsd.org/resources/ICSD-IAS-Founding-Members-1989.pdf Selection of IAS-ICSD Founding Members] In 1989 W. Stegmüller was awarded an honorary doctorate from the University of Innsbruck. After his retirement he was elected as honorary president of the [[Gesellschaft für Analytische Philosophie]] (Society for Analytical Philosophy). ==Work== Stegmüller can be credited with essential contributions to the dissemination of ideas of [[analytical philosophy]] and [[philosophy of science]] in the [[German language|German]]-speaking world. In his [[inaugural lecture]] at the [[University of Innsbruck]], he outlined the four problems in [[epistemology]], which he focussed on in his later work: * The problem of [[inductive reasoning|induction]] * The fundamental role of [[experience]] * The problem of [[theoretical concept]]s * The problem of [[scientific explanation]] ===Logic=== In his books "Das Wahrheitsproblem und die Idee der Semantik" (''The Problem of Truth and the idea of Semantics'', 1957), and "Unvollständigkeit und Unentscheidbarkeit" (''Incompleteness and Undecidability'', 1959) Stegmüller disseminated the ideas of [[Alfred Tarski]] and [[Rudolf Carnap]] on [[semantics]] and [[logics]] as well as those of [[Kurt Gödel]] on [[mathematical logic]]. Later similar works are on "Die Antinomien und ihre Behandlung" (''[[antimony|Antinomies]] and Their Treatment'', 1955) as well as "Strukturtypen der Logik" (''Types of Structures of Logic'', 1961). ===Epistemology=== One of the most influential books of Stegmüller is "Metaphysik, Skepsis, Wissenschaft" (1954). In this work, he discusses the epistemological foundations of [[metaphysics]], [[scepticism]], and [[science]]. He demonstrates that any search for epistemological fundamentals will necessarily lead to the problem of the [[evidence]] — which Stegmüller does not regard as solvable. He also refuses the potential solution that universal [[skepticism]] is [[self-refuting idea|self-refuting]]. Even if it was self-refuting, universal skepticism can be stated if the skeptic does not try to justify it. In consequence, explicit conditions (''Evidenzvoraussetzungen'') are necessary in [[metaphysics]] as well as in [[science]]. This means that neither can be fundamentally justified but do presuppose a decision. A further focus of Stegmüller's work was [[phenomenalism]]. In "Der Phänomenalismus und seine Schwierigkeiten" (1958), he describes the extreme problems, which hinder a stringent implementation of the phenomentalist program. ===Philosophy of science=== Stegmüller is regarded as one of the leading philosophers of science of the second half of the 20th century. Deeply influenced by [[Thomas S. Kuhn]] and [[Joseph D. Sneed]], he and several co-workers expanded upon the ideas of Sneed in order to overcome the prevalent rationality crisis of the science that was often regarded as a consequence of Kuhn's works. Furthermore, this led him to a new answer to the problems of [[theoretical concept]]s. This line of investigations is today known as the ""[[structuralism (philosophy of science)|structural theory of the empirical sciences]]". ==Selected publications== *''Das Wahrheitsproblem und die Idee der Semantik'', 1957 *''Unvollständigkeit und Unentscheidbarkeit'', 1959 *''Einheit und Problematik der wissenschaftlichen Welterkenntnis'', 1967 *''Metaphysik-Skepsis-Wissenschaft'', 1969 *''Probleme und Resultate der Wissenschafttheorie und Analytischen Philosophie'' **Band I, ''Erklärung-Begründung-Kausalität'', 1983 **Band II, ''Theorie und Erfahrung'', 1974 ***1. Teilband: ''Theorie und Erfahrung'', 1974 ***2. Teilband: ''Theorienstrukturen und Theoriendynamik'', 1985 ***3. Teilband: ''Die Entwicklung des neuen Strukturalismus seit 1973'', 1986 **Band III, ''Strukturtypen der Logik'', 1984 **Band IV, ''Personelle und statistische Wahrscheinlichkeit'', 1973 ***1. Halbband: ''Personelle Wahrscheinlichkeit und rationale Entscheidung'', 1973 ***2. Halbband: ''Statistisches Schließen - Statistische Begründung - Statistische Analyse'', 1973 *''Das Problem der Induktion: Humes Herausforderung und moderne Antworten'', 1975 *''Rationale Rekonstruktion von Wissenschaft und ihrem Wandel'', 1979 *''The Structuralists View of Theories'', 1979 *''Aufsätze zur Wissenschaftstheorie'', 1980 *''Philosophy of economics'', 1982 *'' Kripkes Deutung der Spätphilosophie Wittgensteins. Kommentarversuch über einen versuchten Kommentar.'' 1986 *''Hauptströmungen der Gegenwartsphilosophie'', Bd. I-IV, Kröner, 7. Auflage (1989), {{ISBN|3-520-30807-X}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== *[[C. G. Hempel]], [[H. Putnam]], [[Wilhelm K. Essler|W. K. Essler]] (eds.): ''Methodology, Epistemology, and Philosophy of Science: Essays in Honour of Wolfgang Stegmüller on the Occasion of his 60th Birth Day, June 3rd, 1983. Reprinted from the Journal ''Erkenntnis'', Vol. 19, Nos 1, 2 and 3.'' Springer Verlag (1983) {{ISBN|90-277-1646-3}} *R. Kleinknecht: ''Nachruf auf Wolfgang Stegmüller'' (two years after he died), ''Journal for General Philosophy of Science'', Vol. 24, 1–16, (1993) {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Stegmuller}} [[Category:1923 births]] [[Category:1991 deaths]] [[Category:German philosophers]] [[Category:Austrian philosophers]] [[Category:Analytic philosophers]] [[Category:Philosophers of science]] [[Category:German male writers]]

'''Yalçın Küçük''' (born 1938) is a Turkish socialist writer, philosopher, economist, historian and [[media pundit]], recognized for his historical studies on the late-Ottoman and Republican periods in the history of Turkey and Soviet economic development from a Marxist perspective and also his interest in [[crypto-Judaism]] in Turkey ([[Sabbateanism]]) and criticism of the [[Justice and Development Party (Turkey)|Justice and Development Party]].<ref name=yon/><ref name=kimdir>{{Cite news|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/10720612.asp|accessdate=2009-01-07|title=Prof. Dr. Yalçın Küçük kimdir|work=[[Hürriyet]] |date=2009-01-07|language=Turkish}}</ref> He was detained for 682 days in relation to the [[Odatv case]] of the [[Ergenekon trials]] (released in December 2012).<ref name=HDN/> In August 2013 he was sentenced to 22 years and six months, later to be released on 12/12/13.<ref>[[Today's Zaman]], 5 August 2013, [http://todayszaman.com/news-322781-long-sentences-for-ergenekon-suspects-life-for-ex-army-chief.html Long sentences for Ergenekon suspects, life for ex-army chief]</ref>
==Background== Küçük was born in [[Iskenderun]]. His father's ancestry is [[Iraqi Turkmen|Turkoman]] while his mother's is [[Peoples of the Caucasus|Caucasian]]<!-- this is mentioned because the man himself is fixated on these matters -->. He went to the [[Kabataş High School]], followed by [[Ankara University]]. He graduated in 1960 with a degree in [[political science]].<ref name=kimdir/>
==Career== His first job was in the State Planning Board, where he eventually oversaw the Long Term Planning department. In 1966 he found a position at the [[Middle East Technical University]]. He was fired after the [[1971 Turkish coup d'état|1971 coup]]. Before the coup he wrote calling for a "Socialist Revolution" and a socialist administration in Turkey in the leftist publications ''Yön'', ''Emek'', ''[[Ant (newspaper)|Ant]]''.<ref name=yon/> He is also well known for his bitter criticisms of another strategy called "National Democratic Revolution" ({{lang-tr|Milli Demokratik Devrim}}).
<!-- needs to be confirmed: Towards the end of the decade he did a two year stint at [[Birmingham University]]'s Russian and Eastern European Research Center. In a period of intense political tension, Küçük's interest in [[Sovietology]] landed him with an eight year prison sentence. --> In 1973, he became a reserve officer at the Polatlı Artillery school (military service is compulsory in Turkey). Afterward he ran the economy department of the establishment newspaper, ''[[Cumhuriyet]]''.<ref name=kimdir/> He also ran the economy bulletin of the [[Anka news agency]].<ref name=yon/>
He soon devoted himself to leftist causes, such as editing the newspaper ''Yürüyüş'' and relaunching of the [[Workers Party of Turkey]] ({{lang-tr|Türkiye İşçi Partisi}}). The party kicked him and some others out in 1978; so, they launched a magazine called ''Socialist Power'' ({{lang-tr|Sosyalist İktidar}}) the next year.<ref name=yon/>
In 1979 he joined [[Ankara University]] but was again dismissed after [[1980 Turkish coup d'état|the next coup]], in 1980. He returned to academia at [[Gazi University]], and retired in 1987.<ref name=yon/>
==Retirement== In his retirement he continued to write for ''Social Deliverance'' ({{lang-tr|Toplumsal Kurtuluş}}) and ''Always Forward'' ({{lang-tr|Hep İleri}}). In 1993 he interviewed the leader of the [[Kurdistan Workers' Party]], [[Abdullah Öcalan]] in Syria's [[Bekaa Valley]]. Numerous photographs were leaked depicting Öcalan providing Küçük with a tour of the camp, and dining with him.<ref name=yon/><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kackartv.com.tr/Default.asp?I=Haber&ID=15351|accessdate=2008-11-23 |title=İşte Yalçın Küçük'ün Kankası|work=Rize Kaçkar Televizyonu|language=Turkish|date=2008-07-18}}</ref>
Küçük's photographs with Abdullah Öcalan were in fact published in his own books and journals edited by Küçük himself in the 1990s during his contact with PKK.<ref>For instance see various issues of ''Toplumsal Kurtuluş'' and ''Bilim ve Edebiyat''</ref> He asserted on various TV channels and in interviews that these photographs were neither secret nor a cause for shame. As a social scientist and a socialist he analyzed what he claimed was the most powerful insurgency against the Turkish state. Kurdish political organizations other than the PKK claimed that Küçük "Kemalized" Öcalan by persuading him to turn his back on separatism.
He left for [[Paris]] in 1993 as a protest against president [[Süleyman Demirel]] and the fact that a brothel owner, [[Matild Manukyan]], was the highest taxpayer, but returned after the [[28 February operation|1997 "post-modern" coup]]. However, he was sentenced to two years in prison for spreading separatist propaganda (his interviews with Öcalan). He briefly had a show on [[Sky Türk]] called ''Pens and Swords'' ({{lang-tr|Kalemler ve Kılıçlar}}) but it got pulled allegedly after complaints from the government and the former chief of general staff, [[Yaşar Büyükanıt]].<ref name=yon/>
His houses in [[Karakusunlar]], [[Ankara]] and <!-- Tahtaminare Mahallesi Fener Kireçhane Sokağı -->[[Balat (Istanbul)|Balat]], [[Istanbul]] were searched in January 2009 in the context of the ongoing [[Ergenekon investigation]]. His lawyer, Dursun Ermiş, arrived at Küçük's home in Ankara to field journalists' questions. The search warrant was issued by the Ninth Heavy Penal Court in İstanbul. The police were searching for documents pertaining to the Ergenekon network.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/10720408.asp|accessdate=2009-01-07|title=Yalçın Küçük'ün evinde arama|work=[[Hürriyet]]|date=2009-01-07|first=Nurettin|last=Kurt|language=Turkish}}</ref> He was later detained for 682 days in relation to the [[Odatv case]] of the [[Ergenekon trials]] (released in December 2012), and remains under indictment.<ref name=HDN>[[Hurriyet Daily News]], 28 December 2012, [http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/chp-leader-pleased-at-journalist-yalcins-release.aspx?pageID=238&nID=37856&NewsCatID=338 CHP leader pleased at journalist Yalçın’s release]</ref>
